# Recommendations List

### Amazon S3 Security Recommendations

1. Use AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) to manage user access (Amazon S3 Security). SOURCE: https://aws.amazon.com/s3/security/
2. Utilize Access Control Lists (ACLs) to make individual objects accessible to authorized users (Amazon S3 Security). SOURCE: https://aws.amazon.com/s3/security/
3. Configure permissions with bucket policies for all objects within a single S3 bucket (Amazon S3 Security). SOURCE: https://aws.amazon.com/s3/security/
4. Employ Query String Authentication for temporary, time-limited access to objects (Amazon S3 Security). SOURCE: https://aws.amazon.com/s3/security/
5. Apply S3 Block Public Access to every bucket in your account to ensure no public access to any objects (Amazon S3 Security). SOURCE: https://aws.amazon.com/s3/security/

### Trend Micro S3 - AWS S3 Best Practices (file-I1vo7aZHFX7hbAkz2K1LrIGn)

6. Require an Amazon S3 bucket to have block public access settings configured. SOURCE: Trend Micro S3 - AWS S3 Best Practices
7. Require an Amazon S3 bucket to have server access logging configured. SOURCE: Trend Micro S3 - AWS S3 Best Practices
8. Require an Amazon S3 bucket to have versioning configured and a lifecycle policy. SOURCE: Trend Micro S3 - AWS S3 Best Practices
9. Require an Amazon S3 bucket to have event notifications configured. SOURCE: Trend Micro S3 - AWS S3 Best Practices
10. Require that an Amazon S3 bucket does not manage user access with an access control list (ACL). SOURCE: Trend Micro S3 - AWS S3 Best Practices
11. Require an Amazon S3 bucket to have lifecycle policies configured. SOURCE: Trend Micro S3 - AWS S3 Best Practices
12. Require that Amazon S3 bucket requests use Secure Socket Layer. SOURCE: Trend Micro S3 - AWS S3 Best Practices
13. Require that an Amazon S3 bucket has S3 Object Lock activated. SOURCE: Trend Micro S3 - AWS S3 Best Practices
14. Require an Amazon S3 bucket to have server-side encryption configured using an AWS KMS key. SOURCE: Trend Micro S3 - AWS S3 Best Practices
15. Require an Amazon S3 bucket to have versioning enabled. SOURCE: Trend Micro S3 - AWS S3 Best Practices
16. Require an Amazon S3 access point to have a Block Public Access (BPA) configuration with all options set to true. SOURCE: Trend Micro S3 - AWS S3 Best Practices

### General Security Controls

17. Enable MFA Delete for S3 Buckets (AWS Security Best Practices). SOURCE: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/Versioning.html#MultiFactorAuthenticationDelete
18. Block Public and Cross-Account Access on S3 Buckets (CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark). SOURCE: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/securityhub-cis-controls.html#s3-1-control
19. Use Server-Side Encryption (SSE) for S3 Buckets (NIST Guidelines). SOURCE: https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-144.pdf
20. Enable Access Logging on S3 Buckets (STIGs). SOURCE: https://public.cyber.mil/stigs/
21. Restrict S3 Buckets from Anonymous and Public Access (CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark). SOURCE: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/security/centralized-permission-management-in-the-cloud-using-cis-benchmarks-and-aws-cloudformation/
22. Implement Lifecycle Policies for S3 Buckets (AWS Security Best Practices). SOURCE: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/object-lifecycle-mgmt.html
23. Encrypt Data in Transit (NIST Guidelines). SOURCE: https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-52r2.pdf
24. Regularly Review S3 Bucket Permissions (STIGs). SOURCE: https://public.cyber.mil/stigs/
25. Enable Amazon S3 Object Lock (AWS Security Best Practices). SOURCE: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/object-lock.html
26. Use Secure Transport Policies on S3 Buckets (CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark). SOURCE: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/securityhub-cis-controls.html#s3-5-control

**Template**

Implement the principle of least privilege for IAM permissions (AWS Security Best Practices): Ensure IAM policies for S3 are restricted to necessary operations. SOURCE: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/best-practices.html

1. **Enable MFA Delete for S3 Buckets (AWS Security Best Practices):** Activate Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) Delete on S3 buckets to add an extra layer of security for object deletion. Source: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/Versioning.html#MultiFactorAuthenticationDelete

2. **Block Public and Cross-Account Access on S3 Buckets (CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark):** Ensure that S3 buckets are not publicly accessible and restrict cross-account access unless specifically required. Source: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/securityhub-cis-controls.html#s3-1-control

3. **Use Server-Side Encryption (SSE) for S3 Buckets (NIST Guidelines):** Protect data at rest by enabling server-side encryption for S3 buckets, with AWS S3 managing the encryption keys (SSE-S3), or integrate with AWS Key Management Service (SSE-KMS) for enhanced management and auditing. Source: https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-144.pdf

4. **Enable Access Logging on S3 Buckets (STIGs):** Log requests made to the S3 bucket to monitor and audit access, ensuring operational security and compliance. Source: https://public.cyber.mil/stigs/

5. **Restrict S3 Buckets from Anonymous and Public Access (CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark):** Ensure that S3 buckets are not accessible anonymously and that public access settings are configured to block access. Source: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/security/centralized-permission-management-in-the-cloud-using-cis-benchmarks-and-aws-cloudformation/

6. **Implement Lifecycle Policies for S3 Buckets (AWS Security Best Practices):** Automate the management of S3 objects with lifecycle policies to transition objects for cost savings and archive or delete outdated data securely. Source: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/object-lifecycle-mgmt.html

7. **Encrypt Data in Transit (NIST Guidelines):** Enforce encryption of data in transit to and from S3 buckets using Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) or Transport Layer Security (TLS). Source: https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-52r2.pdf

8. **Regularly Review S3 Bucket Permissions (STIGs):** Conduct periodic reviews of S3 bucket permissions and access policies to ensure they adhere to the principle of least privilege and reflect current requirements. Source: https://public.cyber.mil/stigs/

9. **Enable Amazon S3 Object Lock (AWS Security Best Practices):** Use S3 Object Lock to prevent deletion of objects, adding immutability for compliance with regulatory requirements. Source: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/object-lock.html

10. **Use Secure Transport Policies on S3 Buckets (CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark):** Enforce the use of HTTPS for data in transit to and from S3 buckets to protect sensitive information. Source: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/securityhub-cis-controls.html#s3-5-control

Here are the security recommendations related to Amazon S3 contained in the attached file **Trend Micro S3 - AWS S3 Best Practices**:

1. **\[CT.S3.PR.1\] Require an Amazon S3 bucket to have block public access settings configured:**  
   - Ensure Amazon S3 buckets have a bucket-level Block Public Access (BPA) configuration to limit public access, unless specifically intended for public use.

2. **\[CT.S3.PR.2\] Require an Amazon S3 bucket to have server access logging configured:**  
   - Ensure that logging is enabled for monitoring and auditing purposes.

3. **\[CT.S3.PR.3\] Require an Amazon S3 buckets to have versioning configured and a lifecycle policy:**  
   - Enable versioning for data protection and to recover from unintended user actions or application logic errors. Implement lifecycle policies for efficient data management.

4. **\[CT.S3.PR.4\] Require an Amazon S3 bucket to have event notifications configured:**  
   - Utilize event notifications to respond to specific changes and trigger workflows.

5. **\[CT.S3.PR.5\] Require that an Amazon S3 bucket does not manage user access with an access control list (ACL):**  
   - Avoid using ACLs for user access management to enforce a more unified and manageable permission model via policies.

6. **\[CT.S3.PR.6\] Require an Amazon S3 bucket to have lifecycle policies configured:**  
   - Configure lifecycle policies to automate the transition to less expensive storage classes or deletion of obsolete data.

7. **\[CT.S3.PR.8\] Require that Amazon S3 bucket requests use Secure Socket Layer:**  
   - Enforce the use of SSL for data in transit to secure data and ensure confidentiality and integrity.

8. **\[CT.S3.PR.9\] Require that an Amazon S3 bucket has S3 Object Lock activated:**  
   - Use S3 Object Lock to prevent object deletion and ensure that data remains immutable for compliance requirements.

9. **\[CT.S3.PR.10\] Require an Amazon S3 bucket to have server-side encryption configured using an AWS KMS key:**  
   - Implement server-side encryption with AWS KMS keys for robust access control and audit trails.

10. **\[CT.S3.PR.11\] Require an Amazon S3 bucket to have versioning enabled:**  
    - Enable versioning as a safeguard against accidental deletion or overwriting of objects.

11. **\[CT.S3.PR.12\] Require an Amazon S3 access point to have a Block Public Access (BPA) configuration with all options set to true:**  
    - Enforce BPA on S3 access points to prevent public access and ensure data privacy.

These recommendations focus on securing Amazon S3 buckets against unauthorized access, data breaches, and ensuring data integrity and availability.

Here are the security recommendations related to Amazon S3 from the webpage:

**Amazon S3 Security:** 
1. **Access Management**:
   - Use AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) to create users and manage their access.
   - Utilize Access Control Lists (ACLs) to make individual objects accessible to authorized users.
   - Configure permissions for all objects within a single S3 bucket with bucket policies.
   - Employ Query String Authentication to grant time-limited access to others with temporary URLs.

2. **Encryption and Data Protection:**
   - Apply S3 Block Public Access to every bucket in your account—both existing and any new buckets created in the future—to ensure there is no public access to any objects.

3. **Monitoring and Auditing:**
   - Read the Amazon S3 Security and Data Protection eBook for tools and best practices for access management, auditing and monitoring, and data protection.
   - Use Trusted Advisor for Amazon S3-related checks including logging configuration of Amazon S3 buckets, security checks for open access permissions, and fault tolerance checks for buckets that don't have versioning enabled or have versioning suspended.

4. **Security, Compliance, and Audit Capabilities:**
   - Leverage S3's unmatched security, compliance, and audit capabilities to store your data securely and protect it from unauthorized access with encryption features and access management tools.

The information on the specific security recommendations can be found on the [Amazon S3 Security page](https://aws.amazon.com/s3/security/).
